awd_titl_txt: RCN-IBDR: Coordinating the Development of Terrestrial Lidar Scanning for Aboveground Biomass and Ecological Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Boston University supporting a Research Coordination Network to develop a simple, low-cost, tripod-mounted terrestrial laser scanner that can rapidly survey a forest stand and automatically provide an accurate measurement of the amount of aboveground biomass contained within the stand. Broader impacts of this work include encouraging the participation of underrepresented groups through a summer internship, thus serving the broader goal of diversity in practitioners of science. One to three graduate students will be trained in the rapidly developing field of terrestrial laser scanning, providing skills and experience that will help move research and commercial technology forward. Moreover, a widely-available lidar biomass scanner could be the key to better assessment of carbon inventory and monitoring at regional and coarser spatial scales. This would make an important contribution to global carbon management and, in turn, help reduce human impact on climate.

By carefully-designed sampling, often incorporating aircraft and/or satellite images, these measurements can be used to provide estimates of biomass, and change in biomass with time, over large areas of forest. Such information is essential for studies of the carbon cycle and measurement of mitigation of anthropogenic increases of atmospheric carbon dioxide. A second network activity identifies and develops other new applications of this and similar laser scanners in forest ecology and related fields. The research network includes researchers from the United States, United Kingdom, Netherlands, Switzerland, Australia, and other nations who are presently working with commercial and research-built terrestrial lidar scanners to study vegetation and forest ecology. Network activities include workshops to bring lidar builders, users, and ecologists together; smaller technology developer's meetings; exchanges of graduate students or researchers between laboratories; and laboratory and field standardization and intercomparison activities.

por.por_cntn:
This Research Coordination Network, entitled “RCN-IDBR: Coordinating the Development of Terrestrial Lidar Scanning for Aboveground Biomass and Ecological Applications" was initiated to train and encourage an international network of researchers working on estimates of forest structure and biomass through the use of terrestrial lidar scanners (TLS).   A terrestrial lidar scanner is a portable device that typically mounts on a surveying tripod and scans the environment around it with laser light pulses. By sensing the laser scattering return events, such as hits to leaves, branches and trunks in a forest, measurements of forest structure are obtained, as well as a three-dimensional point cloud of the forest surrounding the scanner. This information is then used to determine forest structure and biomass,  and to reconstruct forest ecosystems and complexity.  Furthermore, TLS is increasingly being used in conjunction with airborne lidar measurements of top of forest canopy, acquired with drones, to enhance studies of the productivity and structure of upper forest canopies.  Thus, the primary objective of this RCN was to enhance the use of terrestrial lidar scanning to measure aboveground biomass and lead to new applications of lidar in ecology.  Terrestrial lidar scanners have been widely used in commercial and civil engineering applications but are now being applied to the scanning of additional natural environments, including forests, shrub and grasslands, waterways, and coastal environments for monitoring productivity, change, and resiliency.   In addition to supporting the attendance and presentations of US RCN researchers to Silvilaser and ForestSat conferences over the time of this project, this RCN has also supported a number of international research workshops, starting with ones in 2015 (a workshop held prior to the Silvilaser 2015 conference in Grande Motte, France), in 2017 (a meeting at University College London (following the Royal Society's Theo Murphy Meeting on the "Terrestrial Laser Scanning Revolution in Forest Ecology" which was also organized by RCN members)), a mini-conference in 2019 (in Ghent, Belgium) and a second mini-conference in 2020 (in Helsinki, Finland), as well as supporting a full field calibration campaign at Harvard Forest, MA, USA in August 2017.

In addition to these coordination workshops, the RCN has also hosted a number of in-country collaborative visits to BU and UMassBoston by researchers such as Dr Rachel Gaulton (University of Newcastle, UK), Dr. Mark Danson (University of Salford, UK), and Dr. Deborah Crawford, (CSIRO, Australia), and the extended visit of a UMassBoston graduate student (Peter Boucher) to the University of Zurich.  Furthermore, a number of undergraduate and graduate students (primarily women or members of under-represented communities) have been supported each summer at BU to learn to work with TLS data and participate in data acquisition at nearby Harvard Forest (a ForestGEO, LTER, and NEON site). 

Thus, this has been an extremely productive RCN generating a tight-knit group of international researchers focused on the use of terrestrial lidar scanners (including calibration and guidance on the attributes of various commercial and research grade instruments) to improve the modeling and monitoring of forest ecosystems.   Many of these researchers have gone on to participate in major ecological research programs in their respective countries, including NSF’s NEON program and NASA’s GEDI and IceSat spacebased lidar teams here in the US.
